ngiemboon: À tóŋo Mɔ́ɔnfùɔ páʼ peg yé ge gʉa.
en: He called Moffo so I could go with him.

ngiemboon: Páʼ nkandi yɛ̂ lʉ̌́ la, mèŋ n cʉ́ʼʉ jÿo wɔ́.
en: Since this banana is rotten, I won't eat it anymore.

ngiemboon: Ɔ̀ lɔɔn ńtyé na fàʼ, ɔ̀ faʼ páʼ á zɛ́te.
en: If you are given the job, work it well.

ngiemboon: Ɔ̀ gɔɔn páʼa, mbà à gʉ̌a.
en: You say like that when he's gone.

ngiemboon: Ɔ̀ gɔɔn ngie mèŋ m pfó páʼa?
en: How do you say I'm doing?

ngiemboon: Mèŋ n dɔɔn ńgɔɔn páʼɔɔn ńdɔgɔ ńcÿɔɔnò pi cúa wɔ́ɔn.
en: If I say like this to lie, you hit me.
those of (possessive pronoun referring back to class 2 nouns)

ngiemboon: Gʉa ńdíe pe Mɔ́ɔnfùɔ ńdɔg ńtó.
en: Go look at those from Manfo to bring.

ngiemboon: Tóo ńtóŋ penkʉ́ pi lâ pɔ̌ gʉa.
en: Come and call the children to go with them.
his (third person singular possessive pronoun referring back to class 2 nouns)
his (third person singular possessive adjective modifying class 2 nouns)
his (third person singular emphatic possessive adjective modifying class 2 nouns)
we (first person plural exclusive subject pronoun)
our, exclusive (first person exclusive plural possessive adjective modifying any class noun after preposition or a movement verb)
ours (first person plural exclusive pronoun referring back to class 2 nouns)
our (first person plural exclusive adjective modifying class 2 nouns)
our (first person plural exclusive emphatic adjective modifying class 2 nouns)

ngiemboon: Tâm gwǎ jÿɔ́g mekúnɔ̀ɔn mbà pég kẅɛ̌.
en: By the time Tam was feeding the pigs, ours were out.
